awd_titl_txt: AstroCom NYC: A Partnership between Astronomers in New York City
awd_abstract_narration:
AstroCom NYC is designed to improve access by urban minority students to opportunities in astrophysical research by enhancing and solidifying partnerships between research astronomers in New York City.  The partners are minority-serving institutions of the City University of New York (CUNY), and the astrophysics research departments of the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH), and the Center for Computational Astrophysics (CCA) at the Flatiron Institute. All CUNY astronomers form a supportive and collaborative network and hold resident associate positions at AMNH.  Continuing a program developed with support from NSF's Partnerships in Astronomy and Astrophysics Research and Education (PAARE) program, the team will transition into a sustainable enterprise to provide centralized, personalized mentoring as well as financial and academic support to CUNY undergraduates.  This has proven to be an effective model to improve recruitment, retention, and professional success for students from groups that are traditionally underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

The partners in AstroCom NYC are uniquely qualified for the task of improving minority access to astrophysics research because of their strong working relationships, expertise in mentoring students with diverse backgrounds, and the ready pool of candidates from within CUNY. AstroCom NYC serves as a model to urban areas with large and diverse minority populations.  Their specific objectives are to (1) create an inclusive program to promote student recruitment and retention in astrophysics by supporting students throughout their studies and research with structured mentoring, fellowships, and additional academic preparation for research;  (2) improve student retention and graduation in STEM, particularly physics; (3) create an innovative community of diverse, urban astrophysicists in New York City to concentrate and support otherwise dispersed CUNY students and faculty; and(4) build CUNY students' sense of belonging in astrophysics by creating opportunities for them to work within this unique community of research institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
AstroCom NYC is designed to engage underrepresented students in astrophysical research by enhancing the ties between astronomers based in New York City, particularly between the City University of New York (CUNY), a minority-serving institution, the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) and the Flatiron Institute Center for Computational Astrophysics (CCA). Our specific objectives are to:

  1. create an inclusive program to promote student recruitment and retention in astrophysics by supporting students throughout their studies and research with structured mentoring, fellowships, and additional academic preparation for – and personal acclimation to – the research environment;
  2. improve student retention and graduation in STEM, particularly physics, and thus strengthen the pipeline to graduate school, particularly for students from groups historically underrepresented in STEM;
  3. create an innovative community of diverse, urban astrophysicists in New York City to concentrate and support otherwise dispersed CUNY students and faculty; and
  4. build CUNY students’ sense of belonging in astrophysics by creating opportunities for them to work within this unique community of research institutions.

Our formal education program begins in the spring semester before the initial summer research internship when new AstroCom NYC scholars participate in a weekly curriculum we created called Science Thought and Practices (STP) that helps students develop the required competencies for research. Key skills developed include scientific, analogical, and proportional reasoning, plus general research skills such as data analysis and modeling. STP is also designed to address a number of other roadblocks for disadvantaged students: the course is conducted on site at AMNH to get them comfortable in the research environment, build community, and to be recruited by potential mentors, who give project pitches. Another goal of STP is to modify their conceptions of science and self-identification as a “scientist.” Regardless of their level of study, our scholars’ views of science change after this curriculum. From our formal program assessment, the STP was uniformly credited by the students as an essential part of creating their cohort, building their sense of belonging, and broadening their perspective on what is science.

A significant innovation in our 2018 program renewal was the addition of a dedicated staff counselor. This person has been a truly invaluable member of AstroCom NYC. Through her efforts, students have a much-needed avenue for emotional support via one-on-one sessions as well as a biweekly Solidarity Group. Even alumni continue to zoom in for Solidarity Group, it is so important to them to participate and contribute. The counselor has also helped students develop agency in our community so they can bring concerns to the faculty to affect serious change. The counselor is part of our mentoring team, augmenting faculty professional development to provide specialized support for science students, including issues such as impostor phenomenon and test anxiety, but also addressing broader concerns which can include poverty and stress. Finally, she provides guidance to our faculty about mitigation strategies, and advises on professional development activities on anti-oppression.

The COVID-19 emergency in the US began with frightful and deadly speed in New York City early in 2020. Communities of color and in poverty, our direct constituents at CUNY, have been hit the hardest. Many of our AstroCom NYC scholars and/or family members were infected. They have lost loved ones, delayed graduation or grad school, slipped away from our community due to the isolation of the pandemic, or have simply been worn down by the stress. On top of these issues have been the cries for social justice reform, which strike at their passions most directly and highlight the stark divide between them and our predominantly white faculty. In response, we created Comm2 (“Comm-squared” or the Community Committee) as a forum for students and faculty to discuss safely and openly, under our counselor’s moderation, sensitive issues affecting our interactions and maximizing student support. Considerable time and resources have gone into faculty professional development to this end.

Finally, academic advisement for each student is overseen by a career mentor all year long and culminates in timely “advisement jamborees” in preparation for registering for classes.

Directly addressing our Broader Impact goals, since AstroCom NYC started in 2012, 62 diverse scholars have joined our community, 23 have entered graduate school, and our first alumnus earned their PhD in April 2023. Additionally, 17 scholars earned external research fellowships, one was awarded an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, and one earned a Fulbright Award. Through several state-wide and national workshops, about 90 faculty and postdocs have been trained in the STP practice. Over 125 students have completed the curriculum. We have trained more than 25 postdocs as research mentors. Directly addressing our Intellectual Merit goals, 11 research papers with AstroCom NYC student co-authors have appeared in peer-reviewed journals so far, along with many more student presentations at American Astronomical Society national meetings.
